case_name: Benares Ice Factory, Ltd. v. New Bheerbhum Coal Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 342 of 1959 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 29, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in appeal from Original Order No. 188 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 342 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 29, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court, in appeal from Original Order No. 188 of 1958.

facts.text: In Suit No. 1024 of 1953 on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court, a decree for Rs. 18,497-15-0 was passed in favour of New Bheerbhum Coal Co. Ltd. (respondent 1) against Benares Ice Factory, Ltd. (appellant 2) on December 5, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In Suit No. 1024 of 1953 on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court a decree for the payment of Rs. 18,497-15-0 was passed by companysent in favour of the New Bheerbhum Coal Co. Ltd.,  hereinafter called respondent 1  and against the Benares Ice Factory, Ltd.,  hereinafter called appellant 2  on December 5, 1955.

facts.text: The decree provided for payment of the decretal amount by six equal instalments and directed that in case of default of any instalment, the balance would become payable; a first charge was created on the plant and machinery of appellant 2.

anchor.surface_text: The decree provided for the payment of the decretal amount by six equal instalments and it directed that in case of default of any one of the instalments the balance of the decretal dues would at once become payable. A first charge was created by the decree on the plant and machinery of appellant 2 for securing the payment of ,the decretal amount.

facts.text: A default occurred in payment of instalments and respondent 1 applied for execution of the decree on April 10, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: A default having occurred in the payment of instalments respondent I applied for the execution of the decree on April 10, 1956.

facts.text: On May 17, 1956, an interim order appointed Mr. A. K. Sen as Receiver of the properties charged.

anchor.surface_text: On this application an interim order was made on May 17, 1956, appointing Mr. A. K. Sen, as Receiver of the properties charged.

facts.text: On May 30, 1956, the appointment of the receiver was confirmed and he was given liberty to sell the properties by private treaty or public auction.

anchor.surface_text: The said application was finally decided by an order passed on May 30, 1956, by which the appointment of the receiver was companyfirmed and he was given liberty to sell the said properties either by private treaty or by public auction.

facts.text: The receiver took possession of the property in December 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the receiver took possession of the said property in December 1956.

facts.text: On March 10, 1958, the receiver entered into an agreement with Sukhlal Amarchand Vadnagra (respondent 2) for sale of the property for Rs. 30,000.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, on March 10, 1958, the receiver entered into an agreement with Sukhlal Amarchand Vadnagra  hereinafter called respondent 2  for the sale of the said property for Rs. 30,000.

facts.text: On March 31, 1958, respondent 1 applied to the court for confirmation of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1958, respondent I applied to the companyrt for companyfirmation of the said agreement

facts.text: On May 9, 1958, G.K. Mitter J. allowed the application, ordered appellants to deposit Rs. 3,000 within time and balance within ten weeks thereafter, else confirm sale to respondent 2.

anchor.surface_text: and on May 9, 1958, G.K. Mittter, J., allowed the application. He ordered that the appellants should deposit the sum of Rs. 3,000 with the attorneys of the decree bolder towards its claim under the said decree and further directed that if the said amount was paid within the time aforesaid and the balance of the decretal amount was paid within ten weeks thereafter the agreement of sale shall number be companyfirmed.

facts.text: Appellants deposited Rs. 3,000 with attorneys of decreeholder on May 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order the appellants deposited with the attorneys of the decreeholder Rs. 3,000 on May 30, 1958.

facts.text: Appellants paid Rs. 3,500 to the receiver in August 1957 towards decretal dues.

anchor.surface_text: They had also paid to the receiver Rs. 3,500 in August, 1957, towards the decretal dues.

facts.text: Appellant 2 applied to court to cancel sale agreement and extend time to pay balance; dismissed by G.K. Mitter J. on July 29, 1958, confirming sale.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that when the appellants were unable to pay the balance as directed by the companyrt appellant 2 applied to the companyrt praying that the agreement of sale should be cancelled and the time within which he was directed to pay the balance of the decretal amount should be extended. ... G.K. Mitter, J., who heard this application dismissed it on July 29, 1958, and companyfirmed the agreement of sale.

facts.text: On August 20, 1958, appellant 2 took out notice of motion to deposit balance decretal amount and restrain receiver from receiving money from purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: On August 20, 1958, appellant 2 took out a numberice of motion of an application made by him on the same day praying that leave may be granted to him to deposit the whole of the balance of the decretal amount and that the receiver should be restrained from receiving any money from the intending purchaser in terms of the agreement of sale.

facts.text: On August 22, 1958, respondent 2 tendered a cheque for Rs. 30,000 to receiver, later took it back and paid Rs. 30,000 in cash on September 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on August 22, 1958, respondent 2 tendered a cheque for Rs. 30,000 to the receiver towards the payment of the purchase money under the agreement of sale. Soon thereafter, however, respondent 2 took back the cheque and paid Rs. 30,000 in cash on September 1, 1958.

facts.text: Application by appellant 2 dismissed by G.K. Mitter J. on September 4, 1958; stayed delivery of possession for one week.

anchor.surface_text: The application made by appellant 2 for leave to pay the balance of the decretal amount was dismissed by G. K. Mitter, J., on September 4, 1958. The learned judge, however, stayed the delivery of possession of the property to respondent 2 for a week from the date of his order.

facts.text: Appellants filed appeal to Division Bench of High Court and obtained stay of delivery pending appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then filed an appeal against the order of the learned judge before a Division Bench of the High Court and obtained an order for stay of delivery pending the decision of the appeal.

facts.text: On April 29, 1959, Division Bench dismissed the appeal and refused certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: On April 29, 1959, the Division Bench dismissed the appeal and refused to grant certificate to the appellants to file an appeal in this Court.

facts.text: Appellants obtained special leave from Supreme Court on May 20, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained special leave from this Court on May 20, 1959.

facts.text: Receiver appointed with powers under O. 40 R. 1(d) CPC, liberty to sell by private treaty or auction, not before August 13, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the receiver was appointed with power to him to get in and companylect the outstanding debts and claims due in respect of the charged property and with all powers provided for in 0. 40, r. 1, cl.  d  of the Code of Civil Procedure . The order appointing the receiver also expressly directed that the receiver shall be at liberty to sell the said property charged in favour of respondent 1 either by private treaty or by private auction to the best purchaser or purchasers that can- be got for the sale but he shall number hold such sale before the 13th day of August, 1956.

facts.text: Appellants committed default in instalments and later in court-ordered payments.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companymitted default and incurred the liability to pay the whole of the decretal amount. ... The appellants again companymitted a default.

facts.text: Receiver sold property to respondent 2 by virtue of powers under O. 40 R. 1(d) and gave possession.

anchor.surface_text: It is by virtue, of those powers that he entered into the agreement of sale with respondent 2 and sold the property to him and gave him its possession.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 29, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court, in appeal from Original Order No. 188 of 1958.

issues.text: Whether it is necessary for the receiver in selling immoveable property in execution proceedings to issue a proclamation as required by 0. 21, r. 66 of the Code.

holdings.text: The provisions of O. 21, r. 89 do not apply to a sale held by a receiver appointed in execution proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the High Court was right is refusing to entertain the appellants application under 0. 21, r. 89.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Receiver sales under O.40 R.1(d) do not require proclamation under O.21 R.66, rendering condition (b) of R.89 impossible to satisfy.

holdings.text: The provisions of O. 21, r. 66 do not apply to sales held by receivers.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there can be no doubt that the provisions of the said rule do not apply to sales held by receivers. No decision has been cited before us where a contrary view has been expressed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: R.66 applies to court-ordered public auctions, not to receiver sales authorized under O.40 where court appoints receiver as mode of execution under S.51.

holdings.text: Court's jurisdiction under S.151 cannot be invoked to set aside the sale due to appellants' repeated defaults and laches.

anchor.surface_text: Under such circumstances, if the learned judge who heard their application as well as the appellate court came to the conclusion that the courts jurisdiction under s. 151 cannot be invoked by the appellants, we do not see how we can interfere with the said decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants given multiple opportunities to pay but defaulted; no specific plea under S.151 raised; discretion exercised against interference despite hardship.

holdings.text: The order dated May 9, 1958 is a composite order providing for confirmation of sale on default, not a conditional order.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that this order is not a conditional order at all. It is a composite order. It provided for the payment of the decretal amount by the appellants and in that sense gave an opportunity to the appellants to avoid the sale of their property but, on the other hand,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order gave opportunity to pay but explicitly confirmed sale on default; principle from S.M. Sudevi Devi inapplicable as not ex parte conditional order.

holdings.text: The decision is confined to the narrow question whether O.21 R.89 applies to receiver sales; general applicability of O.21 provisions not decided.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal we do not propose to consider or decide the general question about the character of the sale held by the receiver nor do we propose to attempt to specify which provisions of 0. 21 will apply to such sales and which will not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly limiting scope to avoid deciding broader issues despite divergence in Calcutta High Court precedents.

precedents.citation: S.M. Sudevi Devi v. Sovaram Agarwallah 1 ... 1 1906 10 C.W.N. 306.

anchor.surface_text: This argument is based on a decision of the Calcutta High Court in S.M. Sudevi Devi v. Sovaram Agarwallah 1 . In that case Woodroffe, J., was dealing with a conditional decree which entitled the decreeholder, on the default of the defendant, to apply to the court which passed the decree to direct the ejectment of the defendant.

precedents.case_name: S.M. Sudevi Devi v. Sovaram Agarwallah
precedents.cited_proposition: court has inherent power to set aside an ex parte order on proper cause being shown in context of conditional decree
precedents.cited_holding: a court had inherent power to deal with an application to set aside an order made ex parte, on a proper case being substantiated

precedents.citation: Minatoonnessa Bibee Ors. v. Khatoonnessa Bibee Ors. 1 ... 1 1894 I.L.R. 21 Cal. 479.

anchor.surface_text: In Minatoonnessa Bibee Ors. v. Khatoonnessa Bibee Ors. 1 , Mr. Justice Sale, held that the purchaser at a receivers sale is entitled to obtain the assistance of the court in obtaining the possession under the provisions of the Code relating to sales in suits.

precedents.cited_proposition: sales by receivers are similar to court sales and attract provisions of the Code for sales in suits, purchaser entitled to possession under those provisions

precedents.citation: Gulam Hossein Cassim Ariff v. Fatima Begum 2 ... 2 1910 16 C.W.N. 394.

anchor.surface_text: In Gulam Hossein Cassim Ariff v. Fatima Begum 2 Mr. Justice Fletcher, has taken a contrary view. He has held that a sale by a receiver under the direction of court is not a sale by court and in such a sale the court does not grant a sale certificate nor does it confirm the sale.

precedents.case_name: Gulam Hossein Cassim Ariff v. Fatima Begum
precedents.cited_proposition: sale by receiver under direction of court is not a sale by the court; court does not confirm the sale or grant sale certificate

precedents.citation: Jogemaya Dasee v. Akhoy Coomar Das 1 ... 1 1912 I.L.R. 40 Cal. 140.

anchor.surface_text: Fletcher, J., adhered to the same view in Jogemaya Dasee v. Akhoy Coomar Das 1 . In that case the learned judge was dealing with the sale of properties by the Commissioner of Partition, and he held that such a sale is not one by the court but is one made by the Commissioner of Partition under the authority of the court.

precedents.case_name: Jogemaya Dasee v. Akhoy Coomar Das
precedents.cited_proposition: sale by Commissioner of Partition (analogous to receiver) is not by the court but under authority of court

precedents.citation: Basir Ali v. Hafiz Nazir Ali 2 ... 2 1916 I.L.R. 43 Cal. 124.

anchor.surface_text: Chaudhuri, J., considered the same question in Basir Ali v. Hafiz Nazir Ali 2  and held that in all sales whether by the court or under the court or by direction of the court out of court the purchaser is bound to satisfy himself of the value, quality and title of the thing sold just as much as if he were purchasing the same under a private contract.

precedents.case_name: Basir Ali v. Hafiz Nazir Ali
precedents.cited_proposition: in sales by or under court, purchaser must verify title himself; sales certificate is evidence of transfer, not the transfer itself

precedents.citation: Rani Bala Bose v. Hirendra Chandra Ghose 3 ... 3 1948 52 C.W.N. 739.

anchor.surface_text: In Rani Bala Bose v. Hirendra Chandra Ghose Chakravarti, J., as he then was, has incidentally referred to this conflict of judicial opinion in the Calcutta High Court, and has indicated his preference for the view taken by Sale, J., though he has been careful enough to add that he was not deciding the point

precedents.case_name: Rani Bala Bose v. Hirendra Chandra Ghose
precedents.cited_proposition: preference for view that receiver sales are court sales
